channel.title: New York Times: Technology
channel.description: Headlines, abstracts and links for the latest New York Times articles.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2003 The New York Times Company

item.title: Political Points in the World's Fair of Technology
item.description: Today, artists with a political point to make put their work on the Internet. As one might expect, the quality of the works varies widely.
item.author: Matthew Mirapaul

item.title: Turning a Digital Database Into Local Radio
item.description: For nearly two years, technology has allowed Carson Daly, host of "Carson Daly Most Requested," to cozy up to listeners.
item.author: David F. Gallagher

item.title: Selling Funeral Supplies Online
item.description: Industry executives say there is growing consumer interest in being able to shop online for funeral needs.
item.author: Bob Tedeschi

item.title: Labeling CD's Without the Peel-and-Stick Risk
item.description: High-speed CD-ROM drives provide faster data transfers, but they can run into trouble with self-adhesive CD labels.
item.author: Ian Austen

item.title: Virtual World, Real Money, and a Chance to Make More
item.description: For many people, one of the chief attractions of role-playing games is the chance to escape from reality.
item.author: Adam Baer

item.title: 'Everyone I Know' and Children's Art
item.description: Everyone I Know.
item.author: Pamela Licalzi O'connell

item.title: Sound-and-Light Show as a Stress Reducer
item.description: Can machines that produce flickering lights and synchronized audio tones similarly help you relax? Yes, say the users of sound and light machines.
item.author: Howard Millman

item.title: For the Mix Tape, a Digital Upgrade and Notoriety
item.description: In the age of digital files and the CD burner, homemade music compilations have become bigger than ever.
item.author: David F. Gallagher

item.title: Movies or Music Files? A Jukebox Does Double Duty
item.description: Archos Multimedia Jukebox 20 comes with a color liquid crystal display screen right on the front to display digital photographs and play video clips in the MPEG-4 format.
item.author: J.d. Biersdorfer

item.title: You Are Here. Now, Turn Right (and Hurry).
item.description: For people who are frequently on the road, a new G.P.S. package can also save time and frustration by automatically tapping into addresses stored in Microsoft Outlook
item.author: J.d. Biersdorfer

item.title: Just When You Need It, a Nudge From an Online Nag
item.description: Need to track a project or a to-do list? Look online.
item.author: Sarah Milstein

item.title: MPEG 1, 2, and Now 4: Shrinking Video Files
item.description: Q. What is the difference between the MPEG-1, MPEG-2 and MPEG-4 video formats?

item.title: Uprooted Gardener Sketches a New Eden
item.description: Its cold outside. That means the time is ripe for planning your summer garden.

item.title: Operator, Get Me the Web Server
item.description: With the right setup, its now easier to use your computer to make phone calls.
item.author: Sarah Milstein

item.title: Red Light, Green Light: A 2-Tone L.E.D. to Simplify Screens
item.description: A diode that glows in two colors may pave the way for simpler displays.
item.author: Ian Austen

item.title: Under 'Tempo,' Click on 'Presto'
item.description: This week, the Boston Symphony Orchestra will inaugurate the BSO Online Conservatory, an interactive multimedia service, on its Web site.
item.author: James R. Oestreich

item.title: Tests Keep Coming for AOL Time Warner's Well-Tested Chief
item.description: Richard D. Parsons must now to work to persuade investors that he is suited to lead AOL Time Warner out of the rubble.
item.author: David D. Kirkpatrick

item.title: Europe Said to Agree on Microsoft Privacy Issues
item.description: Data-protection officials from the European Union will ask Microsoft to make additional changes to Passport, its online customer authentication system.
item.author: The New York Times

item.title: AOL Reporting Further Losses; Turner Resigns
item.description: AOL Time Warner said that it was writing down the value of the AOL division by about $35 billion, and Ted Turner said he would step down as vice chairman.
item.author: David D. Kirkpatrick and Jim Rutenberg

item.title: Electronic Arts Posts 89% Earnings Increase
item.description: Buoyed by games like Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers and Madden N.F.L. 2003, Electronic Arts reported earnings that far exceeded Wall Street's expectations.
item.author: Matt Richtel

item.title: Online Bank Tries to Lure Skittish Investors
item.description: ING Direct has gained a profitable foothold by wooing customers fed up with the minuscule interest rates offered by most banks.
item.author: Jane L. Levere

item.title: D.I.Y. Tools That Leave Spam D.O.A.
item.description: To cope with junk e-mail messages, or spam, computer users can take matters into their own hands with do-it-yourself programs.
item.author: J. D. Biersdorfer

item.title: In Net Attacks, Defining the Right to Know
item.description: As more companies are hit by hackers and cybercrime, the question for many computer users is, how much do consumers need to know?
item.author: Katie Hafner with John Biggs

item.title: West Coast Law Firm Closing After Dot-Com Collapse
item.description: Partners at Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison have decided to wind down the firm that rose flamboyantly on the Internet boom.
item.author: Jonathan Glater

item.title: One-Two Punch for Investors: AOL and Cable Unit
item.description: AOL Time Warner's gloomy financial report shows that the company's problems have spread to Time Warner's cable systems.
item.author: Geraldine Fabrikant with Landon Thomas Jr.

item.title: Microsoft to Alter Online System to Satisfy Europe
item.description: To avert a clash with European regulators, Microsoft has agreed to make "radical" changes in its online authentication system.
item.author: Paul Meller

item.title: State Department Link Will Open Visa Database to Police Officers
item.description: Law enforcement officials will soon have access to a database of 50 million overseas applications for U.S. visas.
item.author: Jennifer 8. Lee

item.title: Putin, Dobby and the Axis of Weirdness
item.description: The supposed resemblance between Russian President Vladimir V. Putin and Harry Potter House-Elf Dobby has become something of an event in media circles and on the Internet.
item.author: Michael Wines

item.title: Pentagon and Companies in Agreement on Spectrum
item.description: Technology companies and the Pentagon have reached an agreement to unlock a swath of spectrum for the next generation of wireless devices.
item.author: Jennifer 8. Lee

item.title: A Green Car That the Energy Industry Loves
item.description: In his State of the Union address last week, President Bush seemed to embrace the holy grail of the environmental movement: a push to the hydrogen economy.
item.author: Ryan Lizza

item.title: Departing Security Official Highlights Cyber Threat
item.description: Richard A. Clarke accompanied his Friday resignation as President Bush's adviser for cyberspace security with a warning on the peril of computer attacks.
item.author: Judith Miller

item.title: In Job Search, Warm and Fuzzy Beats Online and All-Business
item.description: Young people, it seems, tend to place great faith in their Internet skills and lack familiarity with the personal approach that many employers are seeking.
item.author: Melinda Ligos

item.title: Online Calculator Computes Incentives
item.description: Companies trying to decide whether to remain in or relocate to lower Manhattan have two new online tools.
item.author: The New York Times

item.title: Solving the Cellphone Maze One Twist at a Time
item.description: Finding the best plan with the right number of minutes at the right time of day and a phone that does what you want it to do can be overwhelming.
item.author: Karen Alexander

item.title: AOL's Need: A New Vision
item.description: AOL Time Warner must now wriggle out of a financial straitjacket of heavy debt and stagnant profits.
item.author: Geraldine Fabrikant and David D. Kirkpatrick

item.title: Sony Again Turns to Design to Lift Electronics
item.description: In order to keep charging a premium for its products, Sony executives are convinced that the company must emphasize styling.
item.author: Ken Belson

item.title: Sirius Tries to Sell Pay Radio
item.description: Sirius Satellite Radio is starting a campaign intended to remind music lovers of the annoying things they can turn off by turning Sirius on.
item.author: Barnaby J. Feder

item.title: Now Dialing 11 Digits, Give or Take a Few
item.description: Verizon had said that starting Saturday, the only way to make a local call would be to dial 11 digits. But some calls went through without the extra four digits.
item.author: James Barron

item.title: Patent Office Gains Ground on Fees
item.description: The president's budget plan is expected to return to the patent office about 40 percent more of the money that it raises.
item.author: Sabra Chartrand

item.title: BellSouth Moves to Block Hiring by Sprint
item.description: BellSouth, the third-largest local phone company, said that it was seeking to prevent its vice chairman from accepting the job leading the Sprint Corporation.
item.author: Simon Romero

item.title: Fine Print in Electronic Arts' Results
item.description: Electronic Arts reported knockout performances from virtually all its big-name video games, except the game that may have the most bearing on the company's future.
item.author: Matt Richtel

item.title: As Broadband Gains, the Internet's Snails Fall Back
item.description: Consumers have been dropping their slow dial-up services and switching to faster service, called broadband.
item.author: Saul Hansell

item.title: From Nanotechnology's Sidelines, One More Warning
item.description: An 80-page illustrated manifesto called "The Big Down" is an elaborate effort to generate alarm about the perils of nanotechnology.
item.author: Barnaby J. Feder

item.title: Producer of Comdex Shows Is About to Seek Bankruptcy
item.description: Crippled by the plunge of technology industries and cutbacks in corporate travel, the Key3Media Group is planning to file for bankruptcy.
item.author: Andrew Ross Sorkin

item.title: Competitors Shape Strategy to Gain Edge in Web Services
item.description: The race to deliver Web services will shape competition in the computer business over the next several years.
item.author: Steve Lohr

item.title: Lucent Chief Plans a Path Back to Black
item.description: Last year was harrowing for Patricia F. Russo, Lucent's chief executive. The next few months may reveal whether this year will be any easier.
item.author: Simon Romero

item.title: NASA Web Site Put to Test Early
item.description: NASA rolled out a sleek new redesign of its site just past midnight on Friday. By morning, it was deluged.
item.author: Adam Nagourney

item.title: Rival to Comdex Show Considered
item.description: Jupitermedia is starting a trade show to rival Comdex. The company that runs Comdex, Key3Media Group, is seeking bankruptcy protection.
item.author: Andrew Ross Sorkin

item.title: Spending on High-Tech Weapons Remains at Low Level
item.description: The Bush administration had said that the Department of Defense budget would move money into high-tech weaponry, but the bulk will instead go to traditional armaments.
item.author: Leslie Wayne

item.title: Ericsson Losses Widened in Quarter
item.description: Ericsson, led by Kurt Hellstroem, is the largest maker of mobile phone equipment. The company reported that its quarterly losses widened.
item.author: Suzanne Kapner

item.title: Credit Suisse Suspends Star During Inquiry
item.description: Credit Suisse suspended a banker after reports that he was aware of investigations when he urged co-workers to clean up files.
item.author: Landon Thomas Jr.

item.title: Reviving Romance With Space, Even as 'Space Age' Fades
item.description: Astronomers and space fans insist that the deep human desire to discover who we are in the universe will triumph over the momentary cultural queasiness.
item.author: Amy Harmon

item.title: Cisco Posts Profit but Sales Slip
item.description: Cisco Systems Inc., posted a higher quarterly profit from a year ago, but also reported lower sales amid the technology spending slowdown.
item.author: Reuters
